pt: {sc}strange{/sc} {sc}singular{/sc} {sc}unique{/sc} {sc}peculiar{/sc} {sc}eccentric{/sc} {sc}erratic{/sc} {sc}odd{/sc} {sc}quaint{/sc} {sc}outlandish{/sc} mean departing from what is ordinary, usual, or to be expected. {sc}strange{/sc} stresses unfamiliarity and may apply to the foreign, the unnatural, the unaccountable.
{sc}unique{/sc} implies singularity and the fact of being without a known parallel.

pt.t: a career {it}unique{/it} in the annals of science
the {it}peculiar{/it} status of America's First Lady

pt: {sc}eccentric{/sc} suggests a wide divergence from the usual or normal especially in behavior.
{sc}erratic{/sc} stresses a capricious and unpredictable wandering or deviating.
{sc}odd{/sc} applies to a departure from the regular or expected.
{sc}quaint{/sc} suggests an old-fashioned but pleasant oddness.
{sc}outlandish{/sc} applies to what is uncouth, bizarre, or barbaric.

quotes.t: {qword}Eccentric{/qword} drifters that normally roam the farthest reaches of the solar system, these daredevils fly so close to the Sun that they pass through its scorching corona.
It was Charles Darwin's {qword}eccentric{/qword} mathematician cousin Francis Galton who in 1874 ignited the nature-nurture controversy.  …
In the spit-and-polish Navy, he and his equally unkempt colleagues were regarded as {qword}eccentric{/qword}.

et: borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}ecentricus, excentricus{/it} "not concentric with another circle, (of a planetary orbit in Ptolemaic astronomy) not having the earth exactly at its center," from Late Latin {it}eccentros, eccentrus{/it} "not having the earth at its center" (borrowed from Greek {it}ékkentros,{/it} from {it}ek-{/it} {et_link|ec-|ex-:3} + {it}-kentros,{/it} adjective derivative of {it}kéntron{/it} "sting, goad, point, stationary point of a pair of compasses, midpoint of a circle or sphere") + Latin {it}-icus{/it} {et_link|-ic:1|-ic:1} {ma}{mat|center:1|}{/ma}

quotes.t: To his own townspeople Thoreau was a radical and an {qword}eccentric{/qword}, a man without a vocation, supporting himself doing odd jobs, devoting himself to what seemed to them inconsequential rambles, and living like a hermit on the shores of Walden Pond.
It wasn't until she [Mother Teresa] had set up a leprosarium outside Calcutta on land provided by the government that I began to see her as an idealist rather than an {qword}eccentric{/qword}.

But Mozart was also an {qword}eccentric{/qword}, brought up not as a creature of society but as a prodigious child speaking a language of sound. Mozart couldn't "handle people," as one former friend put it.

et: Middle English {it}excentryke{/it} "planetary orbit of which the earth is not the center," borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}excentricus,{/it} noun derivative of {it}ecentricus, excentricus{/it} "(of a planetary orbit in Ptolemaic astronomy) not having the earth exactly at its center" {ma}{mat|eccentric:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: a person who behaves in odd or unusual ways : an eccentric person
a mechanical device consisting of an eccentric disk communicating its motion to a rod so as to produce reciprocating motion
